Problem:
Consider a continuous-time Markov chain with state space \\(\\{1, 2\\}\\) governed by the transition rate matrix \\(Q = \\begin{bmatrix} -\\lambda & \\lambda \\\\ \\mu & -\\mu \\end{bmatrix}\\). We are investigating the effect of modifying transition rates with a scalar function \\(f(t) = e^{\\alpha t}\\) where \\(\\alpha\\) is a constant.

If the transition rates are scaled by \\(f(t)\\) initially at time \\(t = 0\\), and then allowed to evolve under the original Markov process without further intervention, will the probability of being in state 2 at time \\(t = T\\) be the same as if no scaling was applied?
Explanation: Scaling the transition rates by \\(f(t)\\) modifies the rates \\(\\lambda\\) and \\(\\mu\\) to \\(\\lambda e^{\\alpha t}\\) and \\(\\mu e^{\\alpha t}\\), respectively. This alteration changes the dynamics of the Markov chain, affecting the state probabilities at any future time \\(t = T\\) different from the unmodified system.
